Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Dozens of people lined the sidewalks that had been swept just hours prior, fussing with their belongings, setting up new tents, and discreetly selling wares to one another.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: witnessed by the reporter after a sweep in SoMa

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Many unhoused people, including Robinson, say it can be challenging to identify and retrieve their belongings at the facility.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: shared experience with the challenge of retrieving belongings

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: According to Public Works policy, staff are supposed to provide the resident of an encampment a “reasonable amount of time (approximately 30 minutes)” to sort through and collect their belongings before the camp is torn down.
A federal survey released in May counted more than 8,000 unhoused people in the city, which has fewer than 4,000 shelter beds to offer.
Document Sources.Source Justification: authoritative data on unhoused population and shelter capacity

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: as a recent batch of public records secured by City Hall watchdog Hazel Williams shows, Public Works has bagged medications, wheelchairs, and even a mobility walker from unhoused people, taking them to the city’s storage facility on Cesar Chavez St.
Document Sources.Source Justification: evidence of potential breaches in protocol

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “All they do is tell me to go back to the Hunters Point Navigation Center. And I don’t want to do that. I had bad experiences,”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: unhoused individual who experienced a sweep
unhoused individual detained during a sweep

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Typically, with city sweeps, they give 72 hours of notice with location and time, and we were following that, but they didn’t follow that usual rule,”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Communications and Policy Director for the Coalition on Homelessness
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: representative of an organization advocating for unhoused people

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I personally think it’s a little suspicious to do the sweep earlier. It doesn’t seem like the city wants attention on the encampment sweeps, and I don’t think they want people to see what happens during that process,”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Communications and Policy Director for the Coalition on Homelessness
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: analysis from an advocate for unhoused people

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “the policy clearly spells out how soiled items can be handled and our crews follow the policy and consistently apply its terms.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: official response to questions about protocol breaches

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: According to Mayor London Breed, the intention is to clean up sidewalks and force unhoused people into the city’s labyrinthine network of shelter and supportive housing programs.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: City of San Francisco (via Mayor London Breed's office)

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Mayor Breed's office did not respond to requests for comment.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: City of San Francisco (via Mayor London Breed's office)

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In order to bring public attention to the moral question of sweeps, the Coalition on Homelessness and other unhoused advocates planned to crash an encampment sweep in SoMa last Thursday,
claims for lost property can be filed with the City Attorney's office.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: official procedure for addressing lost property
